captions.text:
Back in the wild romantic days of the Playstation 
1, when pixels were large and masculine and memory

cards were to their modern equivalents what a 
pedal powered double decker bus is to a motor

scooter, there began the Oddworld series. Wherein 
some visionary genius sat bolt upright in bed and

said &quot;What if there was a world that&#39;s like 
primitive Earth, but, get this, everyone looks

weird. And has eyes the size of Jammie Wagon 
Wheels. For some reason I feel like this is a

creative well that will never run dry.&quot; Very much 
the James Cameron&#39;s Avatar of its time, in several

respects, because it initially announced it was 
going to be a five-game epic but never quite

successfully fired the outboard motor on that one, 
merely sputtering along for a few games before

disappearing over the horizon of indifference. But 
back then we didn&#39;t have the experience we have

now with the many failed attempts at cinematic 
universes, from which we learned that pledging

a multi-sequel epic before the first instalment 
is even out is like getting a positive pregnancy

test and proceeding to book a church for your 
child&#39;s future wedding. You&#39;re just tempting fate

to ensure your child is born with no genitals 
or really weirdly into Sonic the Hedgehog.

Oddworld started out with this rather original 
mystical and darkly comedic vibe but in later

games made the tactical error of leaning more 
towards the comedy when the comedy was based

mainly around farts and doing embarrassingly bad 
Star Wars prequel level gags in the Monty Python

old lady voice and was generally about as funny 
as the children&#39;s bone cancer ward&#39;s production

of Othello: The Moor of Venice. So while I 
wouldn&#39;t say the Oddworld franchise never

got off the ground, it certainly never really 
cleared the treetops, and is presently weaving

around the painfully solid giant redwoods of 
irrelevance by remaking the first couple of games,

sort of an attempt to recapture that original 
freshness the way one does with Febreze and a pair

of old underpants. First there was New And Tasty 
the remake of Abe&#39;s Oddysee and now Soulstorm,

not a remake of Abe&#39;s Exoddus but more of 
a retake or reimagining or recidivist or

some other word beginning with RE possibly 
even the one you&#39;re thinking of you terribly

un-politically correct viewer. Let&#39;s not 
waste time and skip straight to the TL:DR

part of the fractious Reddit relationship story 
that is this game - I kinda hate Soulstorm. I

hated the experience of playing it.
But the question I found myself asking

was - is this because of unintentionally 
bad design or from its attempt to faithfully

recreate the playstation 1 era, before video 
gamers were spoiled by autosaves and analog

sticks and the warm, convivial atmosphere 
of grudging societal acceptance? Well,

I&#39;d say it&#39;s a little of giant redwood A and a 
little of giant redwood B. The plot involves Abe,

bumbling messiah of the Mudokon people who 
all look like Teenage Mutant Ninja Tadpoles,

fresh from having rescued his people from the 
factory in the first game, now getting roped

into rescuing another batch as he&#39;s hunted across 
the plains by his enemies, thankfully without so

many fart jokes, but having taken those out, 
the game doesn&#39;t have anything to replace them

with and the general tone of the story is bland, 
with Abe stumbling from one gameplay encounter

to the next without much apparent decision 
making on his part. It&#39;s like watching Mr.

Bean recast as Lawrence of Arabia. Anyway, Abe&#39;s 
Oddysee and Exoddus were back in the day what we

used to laughably call &quot;cinematic platformers&quot; or 
even more laughably &quot;realistic platformers&quot; which

usually meant &quot;character can do an infinite number 
of pull-ups onto ledges which doesn&#39;t strike

me as &#39;realistic&#39; but then I get most of my 
exercise lifting creme eggs to my face.&quot;

So that&#39;s faithfully recreated in standard 2 
and a half D gameplay complete with the classic

cinematic platformer thing where it&#39;s weirdly 
difficult to walk off a ledge. The gameplay is

also based around escorting NPCs, and a game 
based around escorting is so often akin to,

say, a family dining experience based around 
sitting on spikes, but not so much in a puzzle

game in the Lemmings sort of area like this, 
figuring out how best to navigate your dudes

past a few screens of hazards when your dudes 
have all the facility for self-preservation as

a blind hedgehog on a turnpike. Bearing that in 
mind, when I fuck up in a puzzle game I want to

feel like it was because I wasn&#39;t smart enough, 
not because some element of the game decided not

to work the way it had worked before. Sometimes 
your followers&#39; neurones will fire fast enough to

run past the ceiling crusher when you tell them 
to, sometimes they won&#39;t. Sometimes they&#39;ll all

hide in a locker when you tell them to, sometimes 
they won&#39;t, and when the enemy patrol turns around

they all get shot dead before they even have 
time to show their hall pass. Sometimes the

enemy patrol turns around and shoots you dead, 
sometimes they don&#39;t because their AI fucked

up and they&#39;ve stopped moving altogether.
Which gets particularly farcical if you&#39;ve

dropped a mine on their patrol path. Boy, that 
was some really impressive patrolling up to now,

can&#39;t wait to see it again. Oh my goodness, 
is that a reunion performance of The Three

Tenors going on behind you? Boy, missing out on 
that would haunt me to my dying days! When the

elements of a puzzle game don&#39;t act consistently 
the result is frustration. It&#39;s like playing chess

against a six year old who&#39;s just decided his 
bishop can now move sideways and shoot lasers

out of his hat. These are the frustrations that 
I classify under &quot;recreating the retro vibe

genital warts and all&quot;. There&#39;s also an array of 
wonderful fresh new diseases that Soulstorm has

acquired from not maintaining social distancing 
with modern video game trends. For one thing,

it is nice that games can now instantly save your 
progress when you touch a save point without all

that fucking around with double decker bus memory 
cards but when you&#39;ve just lost five dudes because

the helicopter enemies have randomly decided they 
can see through smoke clouds now and want to kill

yourself and retry the area, suddenly those 
insta-save points become fucking landmines.

Oh and we all know how much modern video audiences 
love digging around in the trash like they&#39;re your

mum at a speed dating event, and so there&#39;s a 
fucking crafting element in the game. We find

ourselves having to laboriously check every 
dustbin and locker, all of which are like

fussy prom dates because they require you to 
be perfectly positioned before they&#39;ll consent

to being rooted around in, in order to craft 
items that are essential for progress. Or we

have to scrape together enough pocket change 
to pay a toll on the gate to the next area,

often by taking empty bottles to a recycling 
machine, and that&#39;s not even crafting, that&#39;s just

fucking me about. Rather undermines the main theme 
of escaping from wage slavery because we seem to

have taken over the factory&#39;s fucking janitorial 
services. We also have the occasional cockeyed

notion that this game about carefully escorting 
people needs some action set pieces, so our dude

who&#39;s mainly built for tiptoeing around like he&#39;s 
sneaking off to raid the fridge has to accurately

fling rocks at a giant robot&#39;s weak spots while 
it fires multiple explosive counterarguments at

your bony bum. So in brief, Soulstorm either 
does too much or not enough of being too old

fashioned or too new. Yes, I&#39;ve confused myself as 
well. Let&#39;s just leave things at &quot;don&#39;t buy it.&quot;
